variant.question: Mass refers to:

options.text: The quantity of matter in a body as measured by its inertia.
The force exerted on a body by gravity.

variant.question: For the purpose of completing the Mass and Balance documentation, the Operating Mass (OM) is considered to be Dry Operating Mass (DOM) plus

options.text: Ramp Fuel Mass less the fuel for APU and run-up.

variant.question: The Operating Mass (OM) equals

options.text: dry operating mass plus the take-off fuel mass.
empty mass plus the operating items.
empty mass plus the take-off fuel mass.
empty mass plus the trip fuel mass.

variant.question: Given: Basic Empty Mass: 1799 lb. Pilot + Front seat passenger: 300 lb. Cargo Mass: 350 lb. Ramp Fuel = Block Fuel: 60 Gal. Trip Fuel: 35 Gal. Fuel density: 6 lb/Gal. Determine the Zero Fuel Mass.
Basic Empty Mass is:

options.text: a component of Dry Operating Mass.
Dry Operating Mass minus traffic load.
the actual take-off mass minus traffic load.
Dry Operating Mass minus fuel load.

variant.question: While making mass and balance calculation for a particular aeroplane, the term "Basic Empty Mass" (BEM) applies to the sum of airframe, engine(s), fixed ballast plus:

options.text: unusable fuel and full operating fluids.
all the consumable fuel and oil, but not including any radio or navigation equipment installed by manufacturer.
all the oil, fuel, and hydraulic fluid but not including crew and Traffic Load.

variant.question: Refer to the weighing procedure of a large airplane. Which of the following items are included when determining the basic empty mass (BEM)?

options.text: Unusable fuel, engine oil, galley, buffet and bar
Usable fuel, removable equipment for passenger service and catering
Unusable fuel, removable passenger service equipment and catering
Usable fuel, portable water, chemicals for the lavatory

variant.question: The Total Mass of an aircraft including crew, crew baggage, plus catering and removable passenger equipment, plus potable water and lavatory chemicals but excluding usable fuel and Traffic Load, is referred to as:
The Dry Operating Mass (DOM) is the total mass of the aircraft ready for a specific type of operation but excluding:

options.text: usable fuel, potable water and lavatory chemicals.

variant.question: The Basic Empty Mass (BEM) is 4 800 kg, the Dry Operating Mass (DOM) is 5 050 kg and the Zero Fuel Mass (ZFM) is 6 210 kg. If the Take-off Mass (TOM) is 8 010 kg the Useful Load (UL) is:
The Basic Empty Mass (BEM) is 4 960 kg, the Dry Operating Mass (DOM) is 5 220 kg and the Zero Fuel Mass (ZFM) is 6 040 kg. If the Take-off Mass (TOM) is 7 630 kg the Useful Load (UL) is:

Determine the Take-off Mass for the following single engine aircraft. Given: Basic Empty Mass: 1799 lb. Pilot + Front seat passenger: 300 lb. Cargo Mass: 350 lb. Ramp Fuel = Block Fuel: 60 Gal. Trip Fuel: 35 Gal. Fuel density: 6 lb/Gal. Taxi Fuel: 10 lb.
The operating mass is:

options.text: dry operating mass + mass of the take-off fuel.
take-off mass - mass of the trip fuel.
dry operating mass + mass of the trip fuel.
basic empty mass + mass of the special operational equipment.

variant.question: The Operating Mass of an aircraft is:

options.text: Dry Operating Mass plus the take-off fuel mass.
Dry Operating Mass plus the trip fuel mass.
Basic Empty Mass plus the special operational equipment.
Take-off Mass minus the trip fuel mass.

variant.question:
With respect to multi-engine piston-powered aeroplane, determine the Ramp Mass in the following conditions
 Basic Empty Mass3 210 lbs
 Basic arm 885 inches
 One pilot 160 lbs
 Front seat passenger 200 lbs
 Centre seat passengers 290 lbs
 One passenger rear seat 110 lbs
 Baggage in zone 1 100 lbs
 Baggage in zone 4 50 lbs
 Block Fuel 100 US Gal
 Trip Fuel 55 US Gal
 Fuel for start up and taxi (included in Block Fuel) 3 US Gal
 Fuel density 6 lb

The basic empty mass of an aircraft is 30 000 kg. The masses of the following items are, catering: 300 kg. Safety and rescue material: nil. Fly away kit: nil. Crew (inclusive crew baggage): 365 kg. Fuel at take-off: 3 000 kg. Unusable fuel: 120 kg. Passengers, baggage, cargo: 8 000 kg. The Dry Operating Mass is:
Given Basic Empty Mass = 5300 kg Dry Operating Mass = 5500 kg Zero Fuel Mass = 5980 kg Take-off Mass = 7980 kg What is the traffic load?
The dry operating mass (DOM) is the sum of:

options.text: basic empty mass (BEM) and the mass of the special operational equipment and the mass of the crew members.
basic empty mass (BEM) and the mass of the unusable fuel.
basic empty mass (BEM) and the mass of the traffic load.
basic empty mass (BEM) and the mass of the special operational equipment but without the mass of the crew members.

variant.question: At the flight preparation stage, the following parameters in particular are available for determining the mass of the aircraft 1- Dry Operating Mass 2- Operating Mass Which statement is correct

options.text: The Dry Operating Mass includes special operational equipment needed to carry out a specific flight.
The Operating Mass is the mass of the aircraft without take-off fuel.
The Dry Operating Mass includes take-off fuel.
The Operating Mass includes the traffic load.

variant.question: The Dry Operating Mass (DOM) of an aircraft is the sum of the Basic Empty Mass (BEM) +
By adding to the Basic Empty Mass the mass of crew, crew baggage, catering, and operational equipment for a specific flight, we get the
The Operating Mass (OM):

options.text: Is the take-off mass minus the traffic load.
Is the maximum zero fuel mass minus the traffic load.
Is the take-off mass minus the basic empty mass and crew mass.
Is the landing mass minus the traffic load.

variant.question: When establishing the mass breakdown of an aeroplane, the Basic Empty Mass (BEM) is defined as the sum of the

options.text: Standard Empty Mass plus specific equipment mass plus trapped fluids plus Unusable Fuel Mass.
Basic Mass, plus special equipment mass.
Dry Empty Mass plus variable equipment mass.
Basic Mass plus variable equipment mass.

variant.question: Dry Operating Mass (DOM) is the Take-off mass of the aircraft without:

options.text: Traffic Load, potable water and lavatory chemicals.
usable fuel, potable water and lavatory chemicals.

variant.question:
With respect to aeroplane loading in the planning phase, which of the following statements is always correct?
 LM = Landing Mass
 TOM = Take-off Mass
 MTOM = Maximum Take-off Mass
 ZFM = Zero Fuel Mass
 MZFM = Maximum Zero Fuel Mass
 DOM = Dry Operating Mass

options.text: MTOM = ZFM + maximum possible fuel mass

variant.question: With respect to aeroplane loading in the planning phase, which of the following statements is always correct? LM = Landing Mass TOM = Take-off Mass MTOM = Maximum Take-off Mass ZFM = Zero Fuel Mass MZFM = Maximum Zero Fuel Mass DOM = Dry Operating Mass

options.text: MTOM = ZFM + full tank fuel mass
Reserve Fuel = TOM â€“ Trip Fuel

variant.question:
With respect to aeroplane loading in the planning phase, which of the following statements is always correct?
LM = Landing Mass
TOM = Take-off Mass
MTOM = Maximum Take-off Mass
ZFM = Zero Fuel Mass
MZFM = Maximum Zero Fuel Mass
DOM = Dry Operating Mass

options.text: MTOM = ZFM + maximum possible fuel mass

variant.question: The Dry Operating Mass includes:

options.text: Crew and crew baggage, catering, removable passenger service equipment, potable water and lavatory chemicals.
fuel and passengers baggage and cargo.

variant.question: Which of the following statements is correct? (i) The Dry Operating Mass is the Zero Fuel Mass minus the Traffic Load. (ii) The Dry Operating Mass is the Zero Fuel Mass plus the Variable Load. (iii) The Zero Fuel Mass is the Dry Operating Mass minus the Traffic Load. (iv) The Zero Fuel Mass is the Dry Operating Mass plus the Variable Load. (v) The Basic Empty Mass is the Zero Fuel Mass plus the Variable Load. vi) The Traffic Load is the Zero Fuel Mass minus the Dry Operating Mass.
The Dry Operating Mass is defined as the sum of the...

options.text: Basic Empty Mass plus the mass of the special operational equipment and plus the mass of the Crew.
Basic Empty Mass plus the mass of the unusable fuel.
Basic Empty Mass plus the mass of the special operational equipment minus the mass of the Crew.
Basic Empty Mass plus the Traffic Load.

variant.question: Determine the ramp mass in the following conditions: Basic empty mass (BEM): 3 210 lb. Arm for BEM: 88.5 in. One pilot: 160 lb. Front seat passenger: 200 lb. Centre seat passengers: 290 lb. One passenger rear seat: 110 lb. Baggage in zone 1: 100 lb. Baggage in zone 4: 50 lb. Block fuel: 100 US Gal. Trip fuel: 55 US Gal. Fuel for start up and taxi: 3 US Gal. Fuel density: 6 lb/US Gal.
For the purpose of completing the Mass and Balance documentation, the Dry Operating Mass is defined as:

options.text: The total mass of the aircraft ready for a specific type of operation excluding all usable fuel and traffic load.
The total mass of the aircraft ready for a specific type of operation excluding crew and crew baggage.
The total mass of the aircraft ready for a specific type of operation excluding all traffic load.
The total mass of the aircraft ready for a specific type of operation excluding all usable fuel.

variant.question:
At the flight preparation stage, the following parameters in particular are available for determining the mass of the aircraft:
1) Dry Operating Mass (DOM)
2) Operating Mass (OM)
Which statement is correct?

options.text: The Dry Operating Mass includes fixed equipment needed to carry out a specific flight.
The Operating Mass includes the Traffic Load.
The Dry Operating Mass includes take-off fuel.
The Operating Mass is the mass of the aeroplane without take-off fuel.

variant.question: The Dry Operating Mass is the total mass of the aircraft ready for a specific type of operation but excluding..

options.text: usable fuel, potable water and lavatory chemicals.

variant.question: The Dry Operating Mass is the total mass of the aircraft ready for a specific type of operation but excluding..

options.text: usable fuel, potable water and lavatory chemicals.

variant.question: The Dry Operating Mass (DOM) includes:

options.text: crew and crew baggage, catering, removable passenger service equipment, potable water and lavatory chemicals.
fuel and passengers baggage and cargo.

variant.question: With respect to aeroplane loading in the planning phase, which of the following statements is always correct? LM = Landing Mass. TOM = Take-off Mass. MTOM = Maximum Take-off Mass. ZFM = Zero Fuel Mass. MZFM = Maximum Zero Fuel Mass. DOM = Dry Operating Mass.

options.text: MTOM = ZFM + full tank fuel mass

variant.question:

The Maximum Take-off Mass, Landing and Zero Fuel Mass are identical at 3500 kg 
The block fuel mass is 550kg, and the taxi fuel mass is 50 kg

In relation to an aircraft, the term ? Basic Empty Mass? includes the mass of the aircraft structure complete with its powerplants, systems, furnishings and other items of equipment considered to be an integral part of the particular aircraft configuration. Its value is..

options.text: inclusive unusable fuel, but does not include the mass of the crew and crew baggage.
inclusive of an allowance for crew, crew baggage and other special operational equipment. It is entered in the loading manifest.
printed in the loading manual and includes usable fuel.
found in the flight manual and is inclusive of unusable and usable fuel plus fluids contained in closed systems.

While making mass and balance calculation for a particular aircraft, the term â€˜Basic Empty Massâ€™ applies to the sum of airframe, engine(s), fixed ballast plus...

all the oil, all the fuel and hydraulic fluid but not including crew and traffic load.
all the oil and all the fuel.

variant.question: Given: Basic Empty Mass: 1799 lb. Pilot + Passenger: 300 lb. Cargo: 350 lb. Ramp Fuel/Block Fuel: 60 Gal. Trip Fuel: 35 Gal. Taxi Fuel: 1.7 Gal. Final Reserve Fuel: 18 Gal. Fuel density: 6 lb/Gal. What is the expected landing mass?
For the purpose of completing the Mass and Balance documentation, the Dry Operating Mass (DOM) is defined as

options.text: the Total Mass of the aircraft ready for a specific type of operation excluding all usable fuel and Traffic Load.
the Total Mass of the aircraft ready for a specific type of operation excluding all usable fuel.
the Total Mass of the aircraft ready for a specific type of operation excluding all Traffic Load.

variant.question:
The Basic Empty Mass (BEM) of an aircraft is 30 000 kg
The masses of the following items are Catering 300kg Crew 600kg Trip Fuel 1 200kg Unusable fuel 30kg Traffic Load (TL) 2 500kg The Dry Operating Mass (DOM) is

Given
 Basic Empty Mass 5 300 kg
 Dry Operating Mass 5 500 kg
 Zero Fuel Mass 5 980 kg
 Take-off Mass 7 980 kg
 What is the Useful Load (UL)?

Given
 Dry Operating Mass (DOM) 33 510 kg
 Load 7 600 kg
 Trip Fuel2 040 kg
 Final reserve fuel 983 kg
 Alternate fuel 1 100 kg
 Contingency fuel 5% of Trip Fuel
 If the flight is performed as planned, which of the listed estimated masses is correct?

options.text: Estimated Landing Mass at destination is 43 295 kg.
Estimated Landing Mass at alternate is 42 093 kg.
Estimated Landing Mass at destination is 43 193 kg.

variant.question: An aeroplane weighing schedule indicates that the Empty Mass is 57 320 kg. The nominal Dry Operating Mass (DOM) is 60 120 kg and the Maximum Zero Fuel Mass (MZFM) is given as 72 100 kg. Which of the following is a correct statement in relation to this aeroplane?

options.text: Operational items have a mass of 2 800 kg and the maximum Traffic Load for this aeroplane is 11 980 kg.
Operational items have a mass of 2 800 kg and the maximum Useful Load is 14 780 kg.
Operational items have a mass of 2 800 kg and the maximum Traffic Load for this aeroplane is 14 780 kg.
Operational items have a mass of 2 800 kg and the maximum Useful Load is 11 980 kg.

variant.question: The items to include in the Dry Operating Mass (DOM) are determined by the:
